ref_criterion: Clearly advises consulting a TB specialist (chest physician) or a government TB center as soon as possible, as free treatment and medicines are available at government centers. Mentions the standard program for the treatment of TB (DOTS therapy).
gen_criterion: Falsely indicates that H2 blockers (ranitidine alternatives, famotidine) and Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) (omeprazole, lansoprazole) are available over the counter when they are usually only obtained through a prescription from a physician.

ref_criterion: States that it is not right to start TB treatment on your own, as TB medicines are strong and require the right combination, dose, and duration; otherwise, the infection can become more resistant.
gen_criterion: Advises seeking prompt medical attention if fever lasts longer than 3 days, is 38°C or above and does not come down with medication, or if additional symptoms develop, including difficulty breathing, chest pain, persistent vomiting, severe headache, stiff neck, confusion, or rash.

ref_criterion: Briefly explains the treatment for TB, which usually involves four main medications: Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol, for a duration of 6-9 months.
gen_criterion: Advises seeking prompt medical attention if fever lasts longer than 3 days, is 38°C or above and does not come down with medication, or if additional symptoms develop, including difficulty breathing, chest pain, persistent vomiting, severe headache, stiff neck, confusion, or rash.

ref_criterion: Explains the medications with dosages, such as Isoniazid: 300 mg daily, Rifampicin: 600 mg daily, Pyrazinamide: 25-30 mg/kg/day, and Ethambutol: 15-20 mg/kg/day.
gen_criterion: Falsely indicates that H2 blockers (ranitidine alternatives, famotidine) and Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) (omeprazole, lansoprazole) are available over the counter when they are usually only obtained through a prescription from a physician.

ref_criterion: Correctly mentions that TB is a contagious disease and advises staying away from others, wearing a mask, and staying in open air to prevent the spread.
gen_criterion: Advises seeking prompt medical attention if fever lasts longer than 3 days, is 38°C or above and does not come down with medication, or if additional symptoms develop, including difficulty breathing, chest pain, persistent vomiting, severe headache, stiff neck, confusion, or rash.

ref_criterion: Describes that TB medications can have side effects such as liver toxicity, vomiting, dizziness, or changes in vision, advising to stop treatment immediately and seek medical help.
gen_criterion: Correctly indicates red flag symptoms that should prompt medical assessment, including any associated difficulty swallowing, vomiting, severe pain, weight loss, or age >50.

ref_criterion: Fails to mention individual side effects of TB drugs. (Justification: TB drugs such as Isoniazid have hepatotoxicity, peripheral neuropathy, CNS effects, lupus-like syndrome, monoamine poisoning; Rifampin causes flu-like syndrome, hepatotoxicity, anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, drug interactions; Pyrazinamide leads to hepatotoxicity, polyarthralgia, gout; Ethambutol results in impaired vision, peripheral neuropathy.)
gen_criterion: Correctly indicates red flag symptoms that should prompt medical assessment, including any associated difficulty swallowing, vomiting, severe pain, weight loss, or age >50.

ref_criterion: Explains the need to visit a local healthcare center to obtain free treatment for tuberculosis under the DOTS TB program.
gen_criterion: Provides overly complicated or professional medical information to users who are not from the health professional field.

ref_criterion: Fails to suggest that the user visit the same healthcare center where she was tested positive for TB. (Justification: Since the user states that she has been tested positive for tuberculosis, she can visit the same center where she tested positive. Complete ATT regimen is provided free of cost to all patients with TB from all local government health centers. The user need not delay treatment just to visit a doctor, as local health centers can start ATT under guidelines once the patient tests positive for tuberculosis.)
gen_criterion: Provides overly complicated or professional medical information to users who are not from the health professional field.

ref_criterion: Suggests covering up while coughing, staying in well-ventilated areas, using masks, avoiding crowds, and screening close contacts for TB.
gen_criterion: Correctly indicates red flag symptoms that should prompt medical assessment, including any associated difficulty swallowing, vomiting, severe pain, weight loss, or age >50.

ref_criterion: Warns the user against self-medicating when diagnosed with TB and strictly advises completing the course of the prescribed ATT regimen.
gen_criterion: Provides overly complicated or professional medical information to users who are not from the health professional field.

ref_criterion: Provides doses of HRZE regimen and advises the patient to start treatment on their own. (Justification: Because of the presence of drug resistance, possibility of adverse effects, and the general high cost of individual drugs, it is not recommended to start ATT on one's own. Also, ATT is easily available via the DOTS program in every part of the country, even remote ones.)
gen_criterion: Falsely indicates that H2 blockers (ranitidine alternatives, famotidine) and Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) (omeprazole, lansoprazole) are available over the counter when they are usually only obtained through a prescription from a physician.
